conclusion: Consider the nature of the processes and direction of heat flow to determine heat absorbed vs. released.
Adiabatic processes (b to c and d to a) involve no heat transfer.
Isochoric processes (a to b and c to d) involve heat transfer related to change in internal energy.
From a to b, pressure increase and constant volume imply temperature and internal energy increase, so heat is absorbed.
From c to d, pressure decrease and constant volume imply temperature and internal energy decrease, so heat is released.
Compare heat absorbed from a to b with heat released from c to d based on temperature changes.
If temperature increase from a to b is greater than decrease from c to d, more heat is absorbed.
If temperature increase from a to b is less than decrease from c to d, more heat is released.
Without specific temperature values, a definitive answer cannot be provided.
